title: Highland Council wards and councillors 2003 to 2007
text:
The second <a href="general%20election">general election</a> to the <a href="Highland%20Council">Highland Council</a> was held in May 2003, using 80 <a href="Ward%20%28politics%29">ward</a>s created for the first election, in 1999. In 1999 and 2003 each ward elected one <a href="councillor">councillor</a> by the <a href="first%20past%20the%20post">first past the post</a> system of <a href="election">election</a>. Elections are held on a four-year cycle: therefore the next general election is scheduled for 2007.
Wards are grouped into areas. Councillors elected from a particular area become members of the relevant <a href="area%20committee">area committee</a>. The areas are similar to the <a href="Regions%20and%20districts%20of%20Scotland">districts</a> which were abolished in 1996, when the Highland region became a <a href="Council%20areas%20of%20Scotland">unitary council area</a>.
There are plans to use new larger wards for the next general election, each electing three or four councillors by the <a href="single%20transferable%20vote">single transferable vote</a> system. The total number of councillors will remain the same. The single transferable vote system, with multi-member wards, is designed to produce a form of <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a>.
Political representation.
The 2003 election created a council of 55 <a href="independent%20%28politician%29">independent</a> <a href="councillor">councillor</a>s, 12 <a href="Liberal%20Democrats%20%28UK%29">Liberal Democrats</a>, <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour Party</a> councillors and 6 <a href="Scottish%20National%20Party">Scottish National Party</a> councillors.
Now, after two <a href="by-elections">by-elections</a>, there are 54 independent councillors, 12 Liberal Democrat councillors, 8 Labour Party councillors and 6 Scottish National Party councillors.
By-elections.
There have been two <a href="by-elections">by-elections</a> since the 2003 election.
Beauly and Strathglass.
In June 2004, a by-election was held to fill a vacancy in the Beauly and Strathglass ward, in the <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a> area. The vacancy was due to the resignation of an independent councillor. The by-election had no effect on the balance of political representation.
Lochardil.
In August 2006, a by-election was held to fill a vacancy in the Lochardil ward, in the <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a> area. The vacancy was due to the death of a councillor. The ward returned a Liberal Democrat to the council, so taking number of the seats held by that party up from 11 to 12.

Inverness wards.
The <a href="Inverness">Inverness</a> area includes <a href="Loch%20Ness">Loch Ness</a>, <a href="Strathglass">Strathglass</a> and the <a href="City%20of%20Inverness">City of Inverness</a>.
The <a href="city">city</a> lacks clearly defined boundaries. In ward descriptions below "the city" means the urban area centred on the former <a href="burgh">burgh</a> of Inverness.
There are 23 wards in the area:
† Area Convener (or "Provost and Area Convener")

There are eight wards in the <a href="Lochaber">Lochaber</a> area:

Nairn wards.
The <a href="Nairn">Nairn</a> area is mostly rural. Ward boundaries radiate from the town of Nairn (a former <a href="burgh">burgh</a>), dividing the town between all four wards:
† Area Convener (or "Area Chairman")

† Area Convener
Skye and Lochalsh wards.
